Definition: You have been given a comment from some user from the dataset of civil comment, categorize the comment on the basis of Obscenity.

Positive Examples.input: Will this remove the property from city taxes?
Positive Examples.explanation: The comment here is just a normal question without any indecent words and categorized as not obscene. Hence, it is a positive example
The comment uses immoral and indecent words and is categorized as obscene. Therefore, this is a positive example.

Negative Examples.explanation: The comment is abbreviation of indecent word, but classified as not obscene. Therefore, this is a negative example.
The comment has '*' in an indecent remark which makes it to be classified as not obscene, while the word 'shitty' should be classified as obscene. Therefore, this is a negative example.

We've heard these doomsday predictions many times before:

In 1970, Paul Ehrlich, a Stanford University biologist and best-selling author of "The Population Bomb," predicted, "The death rate will increase until at least 100-200 million people per year will be starving to death during the next ten years."

Also in 1970, ecologist Kenneth Watt told a Swarthmore College audience: "The world has been chilling sharply for about 20 years. If present trends continue, the world will be about 4 degrees colder for the global mean temperature in 1990 but 11 degrees colder in the year 2000. This is about twice what it would take to put us into an ice age."

Environmental activist Stephen Schneider told Discover magazine in 1989: "We have to offer up scary scenarios, make simplified, dramatic statements, and make little mention of any doubts we might have. ... Each of us has to decide what the right balance is between being effective and being honest."

I'm all for legalization, and making cannabis and alcohol harder for teens to access, and for reducing impaired driving due to any substance or state of being. But parts of this Cannabis Act are seriously over-complicated, and some parts are just plain silly.  

The stodgy panel have finished their job, and now (thankfully) it's time for them to step aside and let the House and Senate bring a few of the crazier clauses down to earth. 
- Get rid of 14-year sentences.  It's cannabis.  Maybe align it with youth alcohol penalties.
- Lose the 1-meter/4-plant restrictions on home cannabis gardens.  Ridiculous, and unenforceable.
- Grant blanket amnesty to all Canadians previously charged with possession.  Purge the records.
- Allow one-time amnesty for legal possession of the remainder anyone's stash of illegally obtained cannabis.

Keep it simple, and allow a little bit of joy to creep into the legalization dialogue.  It's been a long time, and there's been a lot of harm done along the way.

You are either unaware of or ignoring a significant fact.  A huge proportion of these plea deal situations are not an arrest and a single offense situation.  

Many of them are where a person commits a murder, an assault on someone else and a kidnapping on a third etc.  Many others are where a serial burglar gets arrested on 7 or 8 burglaries, car clouts, etc. and so there are numerous crimes with multiple victims.

Even if convicted on every single crime using police and judicial resources each and every time, the sentencing system will very seldom stack sentence on sentence on sentence.

Instead, the guy gets a longer sentence on one of his convictions and the others are served 'concurrently"  --- a waste of time and resources.  If the DA cuts a deal and the criminal gets that longer sentence without the numerous trials, that works for the system.

The alternative - trying everyone for everything means you have to at least quadruple the money you spend on prosecution.  Won't happen!

Nothing beats a set of good quality studded winter tires on a vehicle but I admit, for some people they are overkill.  For those that only occasionally need to drive in heavy snow, the alternative is to run M/S tires and then when conditions deteriorate, like they can on the Coquihalla, then install a set of cable chains on the drive wheels.  Cable chains are lightweight, easy to put on, and will allow you to drive at 50km/hr on snow covered roads.  Carry the chains in the trunk along with a pair of winter gloves and a piece of plastic to lie on.  Practice putting the chains on in your driveway before you leave.  Get them as tight as possible and then tighten them again after a km or two.  Having a couple of bungee cords to stretch across the face of the wheel to pull the cables tight helps also.  I have a 4x4 with studded winter tires but I still carry chains with me when driving in the mountains.  I use heavy duty v-bar chains off road and cable chains on the highway.

My husband suffered from intense chronic pain(8-9 on a scale of 1-10) for three years before he died. The side effects of the drugs were constipation and susceptibility to pneumonia. I'm unsure how much of his pain and suffering was due to the medication, not the disease. Digital extraction of poop isn't fun, neither is following the ambulance to the emergency room because your husband has pneumonia and is struggling to breath.  That's why it's imperative the prescription for pharmaceuticals is based on sound research. When we give people medication we must be certain it's going to relieve pain, not make it worse.

Nobody is against fair trade with other nations. People are opposed to massive free trade agreements that primarily only benefit the 0.01% The NAFTA and predecessor FTA have done nothing for incomes. From StatsCan:
Between 2007 and 2011 singles saw their incomes drop about 2.5%
Between 2002 and 2006 singles saw their incomes rise about 5%
Between 1997 and 2001 singles saw their incomes rise by about 16% (almost all of the gain was in 1999 and 2001)
From 1992 to 1996 singles  saw their incomes drop about 2%.

So over the 20 years between 1992 and 2011 Canadian singles saw their inflation adjusted incomes rise about 16% - almost all of which it attributable to only two years. It is possible that free trade was "working extra well" those two years but that doesn't seem especially likely.
